body: Hi all, Found this thread as I was working on a relevant gh definition (see attached gh file). I noticed some discrepancies between the geometry generated by the solar fan component and the geometry generated by extrusions of surface breps along solar vectors. Below is the fan generated with brep extrusions. Fast solution but I often get a 'hedgehog' solar envelope in complex geometries than a smoother surface. [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/*DoaauBpe*GaInn5ImFlvceyTm1sSlpZgY*50LnBQeMTkx352R69HFxiD4DGPuuqQyVP5WI4yusPWr7bnBy7Cd4PA2MuEjMv/solenv1.jpg) This is the solar fan component result for the same surface. Notice the space left: [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/*DoaauBpe*E6eza1U5229w1JKAIy5HPgUfRe2s4UB5bFfcQfec7qQtnIAPtUdS6FWNlnVMqAnRUqL*FKCHwbQsFrePKW6Yuf/solenv2.jpg) If I reduce the height of the surface from 100 to, lets say 12m I get a lower fan boundary that is closer to the simple extrusion solution, but the generated fan geometry is thin and creates a tunnel instead of an opening when subtracted from other volumes (that was the reason for setting the height to 100m in the first place): [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/*DoaauBpe*H1dsYUnlm9KSDXHZgVdWB3dJsp4xg7lOGZLnN-vXKn4OlRhD7uD1nBcACXRbwAKWiIlqjh9dvwJX0dybghSKx3/solenv3.jpg) Shouldn't the lower boundary of the solar fan be the same regardless of brep surface height? Hope you can help me out with this. -Aris
